video.title: Learn the MERN Stack - Full Tutorial (MongoDB, Express, React, Node.js)
video.description:
⚠️ There is a new version of this course: https://youtu.be/mrHNSanmqQ4

Learn the MERN stack by building an exercise tracker application in this complete tutorial course. You will learn the basics of MongoDB, Express, React, Node.js, and Mongoose. 

Tutorial developed by Beau Carnes.

💻Code: https://github.com/beaucarnes/mern-exercise-tracker-mongodb
🔗MongoDB Atlas: https://www.mongodb.com/cloud/atlas?utm_campaign=atlas_bc_mern&utm_source=medium&utm_medium=inf&utm_term=campaign_term&utm_content=campaign_content
🔗Article version: https://medium.com/@beaucarnes/learn-the-mern-stack-by-building-an-exercise-tracker-mern-tutorial-59c13c1237a1

If you like robot toys, check out Beau's other YouTube channel: https://youtube.com/robotfamily

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://www.freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Arkrez 2019
topLevelComment.text:
7/11/2022 Here are the issues and the fixes I ran into while following along, none of them were very severe and all but the last one was solved quickly. 

Error at 17:50 line 14 I was getting errors when I included the flags in mongoose.connect(), just pass the uri as the only argument. 

Error at 1:15:23 if nothing is appearing in the console, then that is probably because the page was refreshed when the form was submitted. All you need to do is go into the top right of the inspect panel, there should be two gears click on the lower gear for setting and select "preserve log", this will stop the console from refreshing. 

The final error I got is at 1:45:13 and says "params is not defined", for whatever reason you can't reference params like that anymore and idk how to get around it without making the component a function. The alternative solution is to grab the url in the search bar and snag the id that way. In edit-exercise.component.js go to componentDidMount() at the top paste "const arr = window.location.href.split('/');" This creates an array consisting of every step in the url path of our current page. Then in the axios.get() call replace this.props.match.params.id with "arr[arr.length-1]". This gets the last element of our array which happens to be the id of the exercise that we are editing. The ID is what we need to make correct calls to MongoDB. Do the same thing for the onSubmit function in the same file.

(The final solution is not saleable, the more branching paths there are in the url, the harder it will be to maintain. If anyone knows a better solution, please let me know because honestly this one feels pretty hacky)

 Hope this helps someone!

replies.author: Valerio Caporali
replies.text:
Hello m8! react-router-dom got some changes! You have to modify the BrowserRouter import with : 
import { BrowserRouter as Router, Routes, Route } from "react-router-dom";

Then go ahead and you have to replace all the Route component settings with this:
<Route path="/" element={<TEST />} />

Remember also to give the right structure to the code with :
<Routes>
             <Route />
             <Route />
             <Route />
<Routes />

topLevelComment.author: md ridoy
topLevelComment.text: can you actually learn whole MEAEN stack in less than two hours?

replies.author: Garry Hall
replies.text:
Well, no. It probably depends on your experience. 
If you're not familiar at all with HTML or Javascript, you will likely be completely lost. 
If you don't have any experience with React or Node, you can probably learn from it but you will likely find it difficult to follow, and you will want to study both in more detail.
But if you are familiar with all these things then this video can teach you the steps you need to take to build a full stack application. It still won't really take two hours, because you will need to pause, go back, follow along or copy out the code. I don't honestly think you'll get much benefit from simply watching it once from start to finish.

replies.author: Punkyagogo
replies.text:
​@Deep Learner The long copypasta-ing is actually what turned me off from Beau's lessons as well, as it's too much stuff to keep track of when you're first learning new concepts, especially when it's how a particular stack works together. I have formal training in teaching (doesn't pay though which is why I'm here lol) and this method is actually a bit counter-intuitive, as students will be inadvertedly focusing more on the code itself than the concepts they're supposed to be learning in relation to the code - it's just an unecessary amount to keep track of. If it's just for watching then it's fine but still doable, but for coding along, it's pretty counter-productive. Going line by line also forces the instructor to explain the code more thoroughly.

As for syntax, this still applies even if they already know the syntax since it's not the syntax that's the problem, just the amount of information presented at one time. This is because it actually has more to do with muscle memory than rote memorization, and spaced repitition and introduction to newer concepts is easier with smaller chunks rather than larger ones; it's just how we generally learn. It's also why chunking is such a popular technique for memorization, which is kind of difficult to do with the examples in this video. I know it was just your opinion, but it's something a lot of coding instructors do really need to improve upon. If you have no problems with pasting code, that's fine too, but I think if enough people complain about it, it's certainly a problem worth addressing. Just my two cents.

replies.author: Deep Learner
replies.text: @Daan Van de Voorde well if you are new it is actually better to start with basic concepts and learning syntax and practising by doing simple stuff. This tutorial will be useful for those who already knows some basic React + Node + Express. And again it's just my opinion :)

replies.author: Daan Van de Voorde
replies.text: Okay i understand that, but if you are totally new and don't know the syntax or the concept you don't learn by just copying what they pasted

replies.author: BirbX3r
replies.text:
In case anybody comes across this issue, I figured it out. At this stage you have 2 separate servers. The first one being the backend (Express) that we set up by running 'nodemon server.js out of the "backend" folder. The 2nd one is used for the front-end (React) which is enabled by running "npm start" out of the parent directory. Because MongoDB communicates via the backend, you need to ensure the backend server is enabled as well while making transactions through the UI. 

tldr: makes sure you are running both servers or you'll get a networking error when adding users/exercises.

!! THIS COMMENT IS BEING UPDATED AS I WATCH THE VIDEO !!
The route to update exercises can be simplified down to one line of code, the reason being the Model itself already typecasts the values through a function. Even if you send the duration as a string, it will be sent as a Number to the database due to its type defined in the Schema. Those four lines of code can then be shortened to just "Object.assign(exercise, req.body)". Also, I think it's better to send it as a PATCH rather than POST.

replies.author: Luke Gittins
replies.text: I had the same problem so I decided to take a different route. What I did was create the database locally in database.js using mongoose.connection.once then put it inside a function. Exported that function and required it in the users.model.js file. Called the database connection method inside the users.model.js file so the database would make the connection each time. Kept all the schema the same inside the model file and then exported the model. Then when you require the model from users.model.js in the users.js routing file it should work fine. I found that my code wasn’t even connecting to the database to make any of the GET or POST actions happen, so that’s how I come up with this solution. Hope this helps someone

replies.author: UserNameJemand
replies.text:
see, this is the problem of poor teaching, he's not telling about event handler binding. In short, onChangeUsername won't work because it doesn't have access to state Object of the Component's child class which is CreateExercises. THIS in JS return a reference to the Object it's calling IF function was called as a method of that Object, e.g: obj.method(), otherwise it'll return a window object (in strict mode: undefined). So in order make onChangeUsername and other functions to work the constructor of the class should be called along with super() to have access to the Object it's trying to affect.
Actually all of that redundant code could be easily avoided. Just use arrow functions instead:
onChangeUsername(e) {...} should be onChangeUsername = e => {...}, as well as all other event handlers like onChangeDescription etc.
And all that constructor, super, this...bind.this(...) can be deleted. lines 4 - 11 and just leave state outside constructor, constructor is no longer needed. Also rewtite this.state = [...] to state = [...]

Arrow functions are not rebinding THIS.

topLevelComment.author: Pearls & Swine
topLevelComment.text:
No offense, but this is a terrible tutorial.  You're kinda just copying and pasting code, for the most part, and just quickly and briefly explaining what it does.  On top of that, his lecture is all over the place.  You can tell he has a difficult time organizing his thoughts.


Reading the comments reveals to me why so many people try and fail to become web developers.  They watch tutorials that really only teach them how to memorize (or copy and paste) particular syntax, and they get excited because "it works", and they actually walk away thinking they learned something.  Then they make the surprised Pikachu face when they discover that they can't actually rebuild the app from scratch or debug problems that arise.



Again, this is not a video where you "learn" to build something.  You simply learn boilerplates and what happens when you copy code and execute it.

topLevelComment.author: Tony Ramirez
topLevelComment.text:
If you're getting a warning when trying to connect to MongoDB or you get a timed out return from the promise there are 2 things that I would try before breaking your keyboard. 


1: add { useUnifiedTopology: true } to the MongoClient constructor. 


2: If your password contains any special characters like "p@ssw0rd'9'!", you would need to encode your password as: p%40ssw0rd%279%27%21 using the ASCII Codes Table.

topLevelComment.author: Scott Sum
topLevelComment.text:
why do the methods such as onChangeUsername take a parameter e but in the html form, there is 
"onChange={this.onChangeUsername}". Why does the this.onChangeUsername not take a parameter?

replies.author: Phillip
replies.text: The html form is setting the "onChange" property (a function pointer property) to point at our onChangeUsername function. When you use the form, it will internally do the equivalent of onChange(<theParamHere>), which will in turn call our onChangeUsername and pass it the parameter we capture as "e".

replies.author: Matus Muransky
replies.text: @JMGei first of all thanks a lot for reaching out! I figured out the problem myself... It was react issue, to be precise the problem was with the set state method and axios calls, because i was making the call and setting state one at a a time and in react docs it says that setState does not update state instantly, so i had to make all of the calls at once and then set the state all at once, that way the component was provided all of the data it was supposed to:)

topLevelComment.author: Jared Roder
topLevelComment.text:
Hey Beau, great tutorial!

I got tripped up when trying to execute the first request to add a user to our DB.  I received an error saying 'admin user not authorized'. It turns out that the first user you create in Atlas has the role 'Atlas Admin' which doesn't have DB read/write permissions. I created a new user with role 'read write any database' and updated my connection string with this new user's credentials. After that my requests started working! Hope this helps anyone who may have run into the same issue.

topLevelComment.author: Himanshu Sharma
topLevelComment.text: Hey freecodecamp, thanks a lott for all these free tutorials and lessons. We are really grateful. I would just like to give a feedback. Your channel is great but it's kinda like jack of all trades, but master of nothing. The channel has lessons for all the different kinds of languages, frameworks, libraries etc, but if someone would like to learn a particular language in depth, then there aren't lessons for going really in depth. I learnt the basics of c++ from the c++ basics lessons, but after that the were no in depth intermediate or advanced lessons to go through. Now, you guys don't have to do it for free. You can create courses that teach a particular language really in depth and if you guys would like to charge for it, students like me are ready to pay. But we want really in depth courses so that we can specialize on the language we want.
